public.name: postRender
public.help: Post-render is called after the Game Renderer and State.render have run.\nIt is only called if visible is set to true.

public.name: preUpdate
public.help: Pre-update is called at the very start of the update cycle, before any other subsystems have been updated (including Physics).\nIt is only called if active is set to true.

public.name: render
public.help: Render is called right after the Game Renderer completes, but before the State.render.\nIt is only called if visible is set to true.

public.name: update
public.help: Update is called after all the core subsystems (Input, Tweens, Sound, etc) and the State have updated, but before the render.\nIt is only called if active is set to true.

public.help: The paused state of the Game. A paused game doesn't update any of its subsystems.\nWhen a game is paused the onPause event is dispatched. When it is resumed the onResume event is dispatched.

class.help:
This is where the magic happens. The Game object is the heart of your game,
providing quick access to common functions and handling the boot process.
"Hell, there are no rules here - we're trying to accomplish something."
Thomas A. Edison

parameters.name: width
parameters.help: The width of your game in game pixels. If given as a string the value must be between 0 and 100 and will be used as the percentage width of the parent container, or the browser window if no parent is given.

parameters.name: height
parameters.help: The height of your game in game pixels. If given as a string the value must be between 0 and 100 and will be used as the percentage height of the parent container, or the browser window if no parent is given.

parameters.name: renderer
parameters.help: Which renderer to use: Phaser.AUTO will auto-detect, Phaser.WEBGL, Phaser.CANVAS or Phaser.HEADLESS (no rendering at all).

parameters.name: parent
parameters.help: The DOM element into which this games canvas will be injected. Either a DOM ID (string) or the element itself.

parameters.name: state
parameters.help: The default state object. A object consisting of Phaser.State functions (preload, create, update, render) or null.

parameters.name: transparent
parameters.help: Use a transparent canvas background or not.

parameters.name: antialias
parameters.help: Draw all image textures anti-aliased or not. The default is for smooth textures, but disable if your game features pixel art.

parameters.name: physicsConfig
parameters.help: A physics configuration object to pass to the Physics world on creation.

parameters.help: The current time as provided by RequestAnimationFrame.

protected.help: The core game loop.

public.name: destroy
public.help: Nukes the entire game from orbit.

public.name: disableStep
public.help: Disables core game loop stepping.

public.name: enableStep
public.help: Enable core game loop stepping. When enabled you must call game.step() directly (perhaps via a DOM button?)\nCalling step will advance the game loop by one frame. This is extremely useful for hard to track down errors!

public.name: step
public.help: When stepping is enabled you must call this function directly (perhaps via a DOM button?) to advance the game loop by one frame.\nThis is extremely useful to hard to track down errors! Use the internal stepCount property to monitor progress.

public.name: alpha
public.help: The opacity of the object.

public.name: anchor
public.help:
The anchor sets the origin point of the texture.
The default is 0,0 this means the texture's origin is the top left
Setting than anchor to 0.5,0.5 means the textures origin is centered
Setting the anchor to 1,1 would mean the textures origin points will be the bottom right corner

public.name: blendMode
public.help: The blend mode to be applied to the sprite. Set to PIXI.blendModes.NORMAL to remove any blend mode.

public.name: buttonMode
public.help: This is used to indicate if the displayObject should display a mouse hand cursor on rollover

public.name: cacheAsBitmap
public.help: Set if this display object is cached as a bitmap.\nThis basically takes a snap shot of the display object as it is at that moment. It can provide a performance benefit for complex static displayObjects.\nTo remove simply set this property to 'null'

public.name: canvas
public.help: The canvas element that everything is drawn to

public.name: children
public.help: [read-only] The array of children of this container.

public.name: context
public.help: The canvas 2d context that everything is drawn with

public.name: defaultCursor
public.help: This is the cursor that will be used when the mouse is over this object. To enable this the element must have interaction = true and buttonMode = true\n

public.name: filterArea
public.help: The area the filter is applied to like the hitArea this is used as more of an optimisation\nrather than figuring out the dimensions of the displayObject each frame you can set this rectangle

public.name: filters
public.help: Sets the filters for the displayObject.\n* IMPORTANT: This is a webGL only feature and will be ignored by the canvas renderer.\nTo remove filters simply set this property to 'null'

public.name: height
public.help: The height of the Text, setting this will actually modify the scale to achieve the value set

public.name: hitArea
public.help: This is the defined area that will pick up mouse / touch events. It is null by default.\nSetting it is a neat way of optimising the hitTest function that the interactionManager will use (as it will not need to hit test all the children)

public.name: interactive
public.help: Indicates if the sprite will have touch and mouse interactivity. It is false by default

public.name: mask
public.help: Sets a mask for the displayObject. A mask is an object that limits the visibility of an object to the shape of the mask applied to it.\nIn PIXI a regular mask must be a PIXI.Graphics object. This allows for much faster masking in canvas as it utilises shape clipping.\nTo remove a mask, set this property to null.

public.name: parent
public.help: [read-only] The display object container that contains this display object.

public.name: pivot
public.help: The pivot point of the displayObject that it rotates around

public.name: position
public.help: The coordinate of the object relative to the local coordinates of the parent.

public.name: renderable
public.help: Can this object be rendered

public.name: resolution
public.help: The resolution of the canvas.

public.name: rotation
public.help: The rotation of the object in radians.

public.name: scale
public.help: The scale factor of the object.

public.name: shader
public.help: The shader that will be used to render the texture to the stage. Set to null to remove a current shader.

public.name: stage
public.help: [read-only] The stage the display object is connected to, or undefined if it is not connected to the stage.

public.name: texture
public.help: The texture that the sprite is using

public.name: tint
public.help: The tint applied to the sprite. This is a hex value. A value of 0xFFFFFF will remove any tint effect.

public.name: visible
public.help: The visibility of the object.

public.name: width
public.help: The width of the Text, setting this will actually modify the scale to achieve the value set

public.name: worldAlpha
public.help: [read-only] The multiplied alpha of the displayObject

public.name: worldVisible
public.help: [read-only] Indicates if the sprite is globally visible.

public.name: x
public.help: The position of the displayObject on the x axis relative to the local coordinates of the parent.

public.name: y
public.help: The position of the displayObject on the y axis relative to the local coordinates of the parent.

class.help: A Text Object will create a line or multiple lines of text. To split a line you can use '\n' in your text string,\nor add a wordWrap property set to true and and wordWrapWidth property with a value in the style object.

parameters.name: text
parameters.help: The copy that you would like the text to display

parameters.name: [style]
parameters.help: The style parameters

parameters.name: [style.font]
parameters.help: default 'bold 20px Arial' The style and size of the font

parameters.name: [style.fill='black']
parameters.help: A canvas fillstyle that will be used on the text e.g 'red', '#00FF00'

parameters.name: [style.align='left']
parameters.help: Alignment for multiline text ('left', 'center' or 'right'), does not affect single line text

parameters.name: [style.stroke]
parameters.help: A canvas fillstyle that will be used on the text stroke e.g 'blue', '#FCFF00'

parameters.name: [style.strokeThickness=0]
parameters.help: A number that represents the thickness of the stroke. Default is 0 (no stroke)

parameters.name: [style.wordWrap=false]
parameters.help: Indicates if word wrap should be used

parameters.name: [style.wordWrapWidth=100]
parameters.help: The width at which text will wrap, it needs wordWrap to be set to true

parameters.name: [style.dropShadow=false]
parameters.help: Set a drop shadow for the text

parameters.name: [style.dropShadowColor='#000000']
parameters.help: A fill style to be used on the dropshadow e.g 'red', '#00FF00'

parameters.name: [style.dropShadowAngle=Math.PI/4]
parameters.help: Set a angle of the drop shadow

parameters.name: [style.dropShadowDistance=5]
parameters.help: Set a distance of the drop shadow

public.name: mouseup
public.help: A callback that is used when the user releases the mouse's left button that was over the displayObject\nfor this callback to be fired, the mouse's left button must have been pressed down over the displayObject

public.name: mouseupoutside
public.help: A callback that is used when the user releases the mouse's left button that was over the displayObject but is no longer over the displayObject\nfor this callback to be fired, the mouse's left button must have been pressed down over the displayObject

public.name: align
public.inlineHelp: Alignment for multiline text ('left', 'center' or 'right'), does not affect single line text.

public.name: alpha
public.help: The opacity of the object.

public.name: angle
public.inlineHelp: Gets or sets the angle of rotation in degrees.
public.help: Indicates the rotation of the Text, in degrees, from its original orientation. Values from 0 to 180 represent clockwise rotation; values from 0 to -180 represent counterclockwise rotation.\nValues outside this range are added to or subtracted from 360 to obtain a value within the range. For example, the statement player.angle = 450 is the same as player.angle = 90.\nIf you wish to work in radians instead of degrees use the property Sprite.rotation instead.

public.name: buttonMode
public.help: This is used to indicate if the displayObject should display a mouse hand cursor on rollover

public.name: cacheAsBitmap
public.help: Set if this display object is cached as a bitmap.\nThis basically takes a snap shot of the display object as it is at that moment. It can provide a performance benefit for complex static displayObjects.\nTo remove simply set this property to 'null'

public.name: cameraOffset
public.inlineHelp: If this object is fixedToCamera then this stores the x/y offset that its drawn at, from the top-left of the camera view.

public.name: children
public.help: [read-only] The array of children of this container.

public.name: defaultCursor
public.help: This is the cursor that will be used when the mouse is over this object. To enable this the element must have interaction = true and buttonMode = true\n

public.name: destroyPhase
public.inlineHelp: True if this object is currently being destroyed.

public.name: dirty
public.help: The dirty state of this object.

public.name: events
public.inlineHelp: The Events you can subscribe to that are dispatched when certain things happen on this Sprite or its components.

public.name: exists
public.inlineHelp: If exists = false then the Sprite isn't updated by the core game loop or physics subsystem at all.

public.name: filterArea
public.help: The area the filter is applied to like the hitArea this is used as more of an optimisation\nrather than figuring out the dimensions of the displayObject each frame you can set this rectangle

public.name: filters
public.help: Sets the filters for the displayObject.\n* IMPORTANT: This is a webGL only feature and will be ignored by the canvas renderer.\nTo remove filters simply set this property to 'null'

public.name: fixedToCamera
public.inlineHelp: Set to true to fix this BitmapText to the Camera at its current world coordinates.
public.help: An BitmapText that is fixed to the camera uses its x/y coordinates as offsets from the top left of the camera. These are stored in BitmapText.cameraOffset.\nNote that the cameraOffset values are in addition to any parent in the display list.\nSo if this BitmapText was in a Group that has x: 200, then this will be added to the cameraOffset.x

public.name: font
public.inlineHelp: The font the text will be rendered in, i.e. 'Arial'. Must be loaded in the browser before use.

public.name: fontSize
public.inlineHelp: The size of the font in pixels.

public.name: game
public.inlineHelp: A reference to the currently running Game.

public.name: height
public.help: The height of the displayObjectContainer, setting this will actually modify the scale to achieve the value set

public.name: hitArea
public.help: This is the defined area that will pick up mouse / touch events. It is null by default.\nSetting it is a neat way of optimising the hitTest function that the interactionManager will use (as it will not need to hit test all the children)

public.name: input
public.inlineHelp: The Input Handler for this object. Needs to be enabled with image.inputEnabled = true before you can use it.

public.name: inputEnabled
public.inlineHelp: Set to true to allow this object to receive input events.
public.help: By default a Text object won't process any input events at all. By setting inputEnabled to true the Phaser.InputHandler is\nactivated for this object and it will then start to process click/touch events and more.

public.name: interactive
public.help: Indicates if the sprite will have touch and mouse interactivity. It is false by default

public.name: mask
public.help: Sets a mask for the displayObject. A mask is an object that limits the visibility of an object to the shape of the mask applied to it.\nIn PIXI a regular mask must be a PIXI.Graphics object. This allows for much faster masking in canvas as it utilises shape clipping.\nTo remove a mask, set this property to null.

public.name: name
public.inlineHelp: The user defined name given to this BitmapText.

public.name: parent
public.help: [read-only] The display object container that contains this display object.

public.name: pivot
public.help: The pivot point of the displayObject that it rotates around

public.name: position
public.help: The coordinate of the object relative to the local coordinates of the parent.

public.name: renderable
public.help: Can this object be rendered

public.name: rotation
public.help: The rotation of the object in radians.

public.name: scale
public.help: The scale factor of the object.

public.name: stage
public.help: [read-only] The stage the display object is connected to, or undefined if it is not connected to the stage.

public.name: text
public.inlineHelp: The text string to be displayed by this Text object, taking into account the style settings.
public.help: The text string to be displayed by this Text object, taking into account the style settings.

public.name: textHeight
public.help: [read-only] The height of the overall text, different from fontSize,\nwhich is defined in the style object

public.name: textWidth
public.help: [read-only] The width of the overall text, different from fontSize,\nwhich is defined in the style object

public.name: tint
public.inlineHelp: The tint applied to the BitmapText. This is a hex value. Set to white to disable (0xFFFFFF)

public.name: type
public.inlineHelp: The const type of this object.

public.name: visible
public.help: The visibility of the object.

public.name: width
public.help: The width of the displayObjectContainer, setting this will actually modify the scale to achieve the value set

public.name: world
public.inlineHelp: The world coordinates of this Sprite. This differs from the x/y coordinates which are relative to the Sprites container.

public.name: worldAlpha
public.help: [read-only] The multiplied alpha of the displayObject

public.name: worldVisible
public.help: [read-only] Indicates if the sprite is globally visible.

public.name: x
public.help: The position of the displayObject on the x axis relative to the local coordinates of the parent.

public.name: y
public.help: The position of the displayObject on the y axis relative to the local coordinates of the parent.

public.name: z
public.inlineHelp: The z-depth value of this object within its Group (remember the World is a Group as well). No two objects in a Group can have the same z value.

private.name: _cache
private.help:
A small internal cache:
0 = previous position.x
1 = previous position.y
2 = previous rotation
3 = renderID
4 = fresh? (0 = no, 1 = yes)
5 = outOfBoundsFired (0 = no, 1 = yes)
6 = exists (0 = no, 1 = yes)
7 = fixed to camera (0 = no, 1 = yes)
8 = destroy phase? (0 = no, 1 = yes)

class.help:
BitmapText objects work by taking a texture file and an XML file that describes the font layout.

On Windows you can use the free app BMFont: http://www.angelcode.com/products/bmfont/
On OS X we recommend Glyph Designer: http://www.71squared.com/en/glyphdesigner
For Web there is the great Littera: http://kvazars.com/littera/

parameters.name: game
parameters.help: A reference to the currently running game.

parameters.name: x
parameters.help: X position of the new bitmapText object.

parameters.name: y
parameters.help: Y position of the new bitmapText object.

parameters.name: font
parameters.help: The key of the BitmapFont as stored in Game.Cache.

parameters.name: text
parameters.help: The actual text that will be rendered. Can be set later via BitmapText.text.

parameters.name: size
parameters.help: The size the font will be rendered in, in pixels.

public.name: alpha
public.help: The opacity of the object.

public.name: anchor
public.help:
The anchor sets the origin point of the texture.
The default is 0,0 this means the texture's origin is the top left
Setting than anchor to 0.5,0.5 means the textures origin is centered
Setting the anchor to 1,1 would mean the textures origin points will be the bottom right corner

public.name: angle
public.inlineHelp: The angle of this Image in degrees.
public.help: Indicates the rotation of the Image, in degrees, from its original orientation. Values from 0 to 180 represent clockwise rotation; values from 0 to -180 represent counterclockwise rotation.\nValues outside this range are added to or subtracted from 360 to obtain a value within the range. For example, the statement player.angle = 450 is the same as player.angle = 90.\nIf you wish to work in radians instead of degrees use the property Image.rotation instead. Working in radians is also a little faster as it doesn't have to convert the angle.

public.name: animations
public.inlineHelp: This manages animations of the sprite. You can modify animations through it (see Phaser.AnimationManager)

public.name: autoCull
public.inlineHelp: A flag indicating if the Image should be automatically camera culled or not.
public.help: Should this Image be automatically culled if out of range of the camera?\nA culled sprite has its renderable property set to 'false'.\nBe advised this is quite an expensive operation, as it has to calculate the bounds of the object every frame, so only enable it if you really need it.

public.name: blendMode
public.help: The blend mode to be applied to the sprite. Set to PIXI.blendModes.NORMAL to remove any blend mode.

public.name: buttonMode
public.help: This is used to indicate if the displayObject should display a mouse hand cursor on rollover

public.name: cacheAsBitmap
public.help: Set if this display object is cached as a bitmap.\nThis basically takes a snap shot of the display object as it is at that moment. It can provide a performance benefit for complex static displayObjects.\nTo remove simply set this property to 'null'

public.name: cameraOffset
public.inlineHelp: If this object is fixedToCamera then this stores the x/y offset that its drawn at, from the top-left of the camera view.

public.name: children
public.help: [read-only] The array of children of this container.

public.name: defaultCursor
public.help: This is the cursor that will be used when the mouse is over this object. To enable this the element must have interaction = true and buttonMode = true\n

public.name: deltaX
public.inlineHelp: The delta value. Positive if the motion was to the right, negative if to the left.
public.help: Returns the delta x value. The difference between world.x now and in the previous step.

public.name: deltaY
public.inlineHelp: The delta value. Positive if the motion was downwards, negative if upwards.
public.help: Returns the delta y value. The difference between world.y now and in the previous step.

public.name: deltaZ
public.inlineHelp: The delta value.
public.help: Returns the delta z value. The difference between rotation now and in the previous step.

public.name: destroyPhase
public.inlineHelp: True if this object is currently being destroyed.

public.name: events
public.inlineHelp: The Events you can subscribe to that are dispatched when certain things happen on this Image or its components.

public.name: exists
public.inlineHelp: If exists = false then the Image isn't updated by the core game loop.

public.name: filterArea
public.help: The area the filter is applied to like the hitArea this is used as more of an optimisation\nrather than figuring out the dimensions of the displayObject each frame you can set this rectangle

public.name: filters
public.help: Sets the filters for the displayObject.\n* IMPORTANT: This is a webGL only feature and will be ignored by the canvas renderer.\nTo remove filters simply set this property to 'null'

public.name: fixedToCamera
public.inlineHelp: Set to true to fix this Image to the Camera at its current world coordinates.
public.help: An Image that is fixed to the camera uses its x/y coordinates as offsets from the top left of the camera. These are stored in Image.cameraOffset.\nNote that the cameraOffset values are in addition to any parent in the display list.\nSo if this Image was in a Group that has x: 200, then this will be added to the cameraOffset.x

public.name: forceOut
public.help: When the Button is touched / clicked and then released you can force it to enter a state of "out" instead of "up".

public.name: frame
public.inlineHelp: Gets or sets the current frame index and updates the Texture for display.

public.name: frameName
public.inlineHelp: Gets or sets the current frame by name and updates the Texture for display.

public.inlineHelp: When true the Button will cease to change texture frame on all events (over, out, up, down).

public.name: game

public.name: height
public.help: The height of the sprite, setting this will actually modify the scale to achieve the value set

public.name: hitArea
public.help: This is the defined area that will pick up mouse / touch events. It is null by default.\nSetting it is a neat way of optimising the hitTest function that the interactionManager will use (as it will not need to hit test all the children)

public.name: inCamera
public.inlineHelp: True if the Image bounds is within the game camera, even if only partially. Otherwise false if fully outside of it.
public.help: Checks if the Image bounds are within the game camera, otherwise false if fully outside of it.

public.name: inWorld
public.inlineHelp: True if the Image bounds is within the game world, even if only partially. Otherwise false if fully outside of it.
public.help: Checks if the Image bounds are within the game world, otherwise false if fully outside of it.

public.name: input
public.inlineHelp: The Input Handler for this object. Needs to be enabled with image.inputEnabled = true before you can use it.

public.name: inputEnabled
public.inlineHelp: Set to true to allow this object to receive input events.
public.help: By default an Image won't process any input events at all. By setting inputEnabled to true the Phaser.InputHandler is\nactivated for this object and it will then start to process click/touch events and more.

public.name: interactive
public.help: Indicates if the sprite will have touch and mouse interactivity. It is false by default

public.name: key
public.inlineHelp: This is the image or texture used by the Image during rendering. It can be a string which is a reference to the Cache entry, or an instance of a RenderTexture, BitmapData or PIXI.Texture.

public.name: mask
public.help: Sets a mask for the displayObject. A mask is an object that limits the visibility of an object to the shape of the mask applied to it.\nIn PIXI a regular mask must be a PIXI.Graphics object. This allows for much faster masking in canvas as it utilises shape clipping.\nTo remove a mask, set this property to null.

public.inlineHelp: The Sound Marker used in conjunction with the onOutSound.

public.name: onOverMouseOnly
public.inlineHelp: If true then onOver events (such as onOverSound) will only be triggered if the Pointer object causing them was the Mouse Pointer.

public.help: The shader that will be used to render the texture to the stage. Set to null to remove a current shader.

public.help: Enable or disable texture smoothing for this Image. Only works for bitmap/image textures. Smoothing is enabled by default.

public.help: [read-only] The stage the display object is connected to, or undefined if it is not connected to the stage.

public.help: The texture that the sprite is using

public.help: The tint applied to the sprite. This is a hex value. A value of 0xFFFFFF will remove any tint effect.

public.name: worldAlpha
public.help: [read-only] The multiplied alpha of the displayObject

public.name: worldVisible
public.help: [read-only] Indicates if the sprite is globally visible.

public.name: x
public.help: The position of the displayObject on the x axis relative to the local coordinates of the parent.

public.name: y
public.help: The position of the displayObject on the y axis relative to the local coordinates of the parent.

public.name: z
public.inlineHelp: The z-depth value of this object within its Group (remember the World is a Group as well). No two objects in a Group can have the same z value.

class.help:
Create a new `Button` object. A Button is a special type of Sprite that is set-up to handle Pointer events automatically. The four states a Button responds to are:

* 'Over' - when the Pointer moves over the Button. This is also commonly known as 'hover'.
* 'Out' - when the Pointer that was previously over the Button moves out of it.
* 'Down' - when the Pointer is pressed down on the Button. I.e. touched on a touch enabled device or clicked with the mouse.
* 'Up' - when the Pointer that was pressed down on the Button is released again.

You can set a unique texture frame and Sound for any of these states.

parameters.name: game
parameters.help: Current game instance.

parameters.name: x
parameters.help: X position of the Button.

parameters.name: y
parameters.help: Y position of the Button.

parameters.name: key
parameters.help: The image key as defined in the Game.Cache to use as the texture for this Button.

parameters.name: callback
parameters.help: The function to call when this Button is pressed.

parameters.name: callbackContext
parameters.help: The context in which the callback will be called (usually 'this').

parameters.name: overFrame
parameters.help: This is the frame or frameName that will be set when this button is in an over state. Give either a number to use a frame ID or a string for a frame name.

parameters.name: outFrame
parameters.help: This is the frame or frameName that will be set when this button is in an out state. Give either a number to use a frame ID or a string for a frame name.

parameters.name: downFrame
parameters.help: This is the frame or frameName that will be set when this button is in a down state. Give either a number to use a frame ID or a string for a frame name.

parameters.name: upFrame
parameters.help: This is the frame or frameName that will be set when this button is in an up state. Give either a number to use a frame ID or a string for a frame name.

public.name: crop

parameters.name: rect
parameters.help: The Rectangle used during cropping. Pass null or no parameters to clear a previously set crop rectangle.

parameters.name: copy
parameters.help: If false Sprite.cropRect will be a reference to the given rect. If true it will copy the rect values into a local Sprite.cropRect object.

public.help:
Crop allows you to crop the texture used to display this Image.
Cropping takes place from the top-left of the Image and can be modified in real-time by providing an updated rectangle object.
The rectangle object given to this method can be either a Phaser.Rectangle or any object so long as it has public x, y, width and height properties.
Please note that the rectangle object given is not duplicated by this method, but rather the Image uses a reference to the rectangle.
Keep this in mind if assigning a rectangle in a for-loop, or when cleaning up for garbage collection.

public.help:
Kills a Image. A killed Image has its alive, exists and visible properties all set to false.
It will dispatch the onKilled event, you can listen to Image.events.onKilled for the signal.
Note that killing a Image is a way for you to quickly recycle it in a Image pool, it doesn't free it up from memory.
If you don't need this Image any more you should call Image.destroy instead.

This allows for much faster masking in canvas as it utilises shape clipping.\nTo remove a mask, set this property to null.

public.name: postUpdate
public.help:
This is called automatically before the renderer runs and after the plugins have updated.
In postUpdate this is where all the final physics calculatations and object positioning happens.
The objects are processed in the order of the display list.
The only exception to this is if the camera is following an object, in which case that is updated first.

public.name: preUpdate

public.name: alive
public.inlineHelp: A useful boolean to control if the Sprite is alive or dead (in terms of your gameplay, it doesn't effect rendering). Also linked to Sprite.health and Sprite.damage.

public.name: alpha
public.help: The opacity of the object.

public.name: anchor
public.help:
The anchor sets the origin point of the texture.
The default is 0,0 this means the texture's origin is the top left
Setting than anchor to 0.5,0.5 means the textures origin is centered
Setting the anchor to 1,1 would mean the textures origin points will be the bottom right corner

public.name: angle
public.inlineHelp: The angle of this Sprite in degrees.
public.help: Indicates the rotation of the Sprite, in degrees, from its original orientation. Values from 0 to 180 represent clockwise rotation; values from 0 to -180 represent counterclockwise rotation.\nValues outside this range are added to or subtracted from 360 to obtain a value within the range. For example, the statement player.angle = 450 is the same as player.angle = 90.\nIf you wish to work in radians instead of degrees use the property Sprite.rotation instead. Working in radians is also a little faster as it doesn't have to convert the angle.

public.name: animations
public.inlineHelp: This manages animations of the sprite. You can modify animations through it (see Phaser.AnimationManager)

public.name: autoCull
public.inlineHelp: A flag indicating if the Sprite should be automatically camera culled or not.
public.help: Should this Sprite be automatically culled if out of range of the camera?\nA culled sprite has its renderable property set to 'false'.\nBe advised this is quite an expensive operation, as it has to calculate the bounds of the object every frame, so only enable it if you really need it.

public.name: blendMode
public.help: The blend mode to be applied to the sprite. Set to PIXI.blendModes.NORMAL to remove any blend mode.

public.name: body
public.help:
By default Sprites won't add themselves to any physics system and their physics body will be `null`.
To enable them for physics you need to call `game.physics.enable(sprite, system)` where `sprite` is this object
and `system` is the Physics system you want to use to manage this body. Once enabled you can access all physics related properties via `Sprite.body`.

Important: Enabling a Sprite for P2 or Ninja physics will automatically set `Sprite.anchor` to 0.5 so the physics body is centered on the Sprite.
If you need a different result then adjust or re-create the Body shape offsets manually, and/or reset the anchor after enabling physics.

public.name: buttonMode
public.help: This is used to indicate if the displayObject should display a mouse hand cursor on rollover

public.name: cacheAsBitmap
public.help: Set if this display object is cached as a bitmap.\nThis basically takes a snap shot of the display object as it is at that moment. It can provide a performance benefit for complex static displayObjects.\nTo remove simply set this property to 'null'

public.name: cameraOffset
public.inlineHelp: If this object is fixedToCamera then this stores the x/y offset that its drawn at, from the top-left of the camera view.

public.name: checkWorldBounds
public.help: If true the Sprite checks if it is still within the world each frame, when it leaves the world it dispatches Sprite.events.onOutOfBounds\nand optionally kills the sprite (if Sprite.outOfBoundsKill is true). By default this is disabled because the Sprite has to calculate its\nbounds every frame to support it, and not all games need it. Enable it by setting the value to true.

public.name: children
public.help: [read-only] The array of children of this container.

public.name: cropRect
public.inlineHelp: The Rectangle used to crop the texture. Set this via Sprite.crop. Any time you modify this property directly you must call Sprite.updateCrop.

public.name: debug
public.inlineHelp: Handy flag to use with Game.enableStep

public.name: defaultCursor
public.help: This is the cursor that will be used when the mouse is over this object. To enable this the element must have interaction = true and buttonMode = true\n

public.name: deltaX
public.inlineHelp: The delta value. Positive if the motion was to the right, negative if to the left.
public.help: Returns the delta x value. The difference between world.x now and in the previous step.

public.name: deltaY
public.inlineHelp: The delta value. Positive if the motion was downwards, negative if upwards.
public.help: Returns the delta y value. The difference between world.y now and in the previous step.

public.name: deltaZ
public.inlineHelp: The delta value.
public.help: Returns the delta z value. The difference between rotation now and in the previous step.

public.name: destroyPhase
public.inlineHelp: True if this object is currently being destroyed.

public.name: events
public.inlineHelp: The Events you can subscribe to that are dispatched when certain things happen on this Sprite or its components.

public.name: exists
public.inlineHelp: If the Sprite is processed by the core game update and physics.
public.help: Sprite.exists controls if the core game loop and physics update this Sprite or not.\nWhen you set Sprite.exists to false it will remove its Body from the physics world (if it has one) and also set Sprite.visible to false.\nSetting Sprite.exists to true will re-add the Body to the physics world (if it has a body) and set Sprite.visible to true.

public.name: filterArea
public.help: The area the filter is applied to like the hitArea this is used as more of an optimisation\nrather than figuring out the dimensions of the displayObject each frame you can set this rectangle

public.name: filters
public.help: Sets the filters for the displayObject.\n* IMPORTANT: This is a webGL only feature and will be ignored by the canvas renderer.\nTo remove filters simply set this property to 'null'

public.name: fixedToCamera
public.inlineHelp: Set to true to fix this Sprite to the Camera at its current world coordinates.
public.help: An Sprite that is fixed to the camera uses its x/y coordinates as offsets from the top left of the camera. These are stored in Sprite.cameraOffset.\nNote that the cameraOffset values are in addition to any parent in the display list.\nSo if this Sprite was in a Group that has x: 200, then this will be added to the cameraOffset.x

public.name: frame
public.inlineHelp: Gets or sets the current frame index and updates the Texture Cache for display.

public.name: frameName
public.inlineHelp: Gets or sets the current frame name and updates the Texture Cache for display.

public.name: game
public.inlineHelp: A reference to the currently running Game.

public.name: health
public.inlineHelp: Health value. Used in combination with damage() to allow for quick killing of Sprites.

public.name: height
public.help: The height of the sprite, setting this will actually modify the scale to achieve the value set

public.name: hitArea
public.help: This is the defined area that will pick up mouse / touch events. It is null by default.\nSetting it is a neat way of optimising the hitTest function that the interactionManager will use (as it will not need to hit test all the children)

public.name: inCamera
public.inlineHelp: True if the Sprite bounds is within the game camera, even if only partially. Otherwise false if fully outside of it.
public.help: Checks if the Sprite bounds are within the game camera, otherwise false if fully outside of it.

public.name: inWorld
public.inlineHelp: True if the Sprite bounds is within the game world, even if only partially. Otherwise false if fully outside of it.
public.help: Checks if the Sprite bounds are within the game world, otherwise false if fully outside of it.

public.name: input
public.inlineHelp: The Input Handler for this object. Needs to be enabled with image.inputEnabled = true before you can use it.

public.name: inputEnabled
public.inlineHelp: Set to true to allow this object to receive input events.
public.help: By default a Sprite won't process any input events at all. By setting inputEnabled to true the Phaser.InputHandler is\nactivated for this object and it will then start to process click/touch events and more.

public.name: interactive
public.help: Indicates if the sprite will have touch and mouse interactivity. It is false by default

public.name: key
public.inlineHelp: This is the image or texture used by the Sprite during rendering. It can be a string which is a reference to the Cache entry, or an instance of a RenderTexture, BitmapData or PIXI.Texture.

public.name: lifespan
public.inlineHelp: The lifespan of the Sprite (in ms) before it will be killed.
public.help: If you would like the Sprite to have a lifespan once 'born' you can set this to a positive value. Handy for particles, bullets, etc.\nThe lifespan is decremented by game.time.elapsed each update, once it reaches zero the kill() function is called.

public.name: mask
public.help: Sets a mask for the displayObject. A mask is an object that limits the visibility of an object to the shape of the mask applied to it.\nIn PIXI a regular mask must be a PIXI.Graphics object. This allows for much faster masking in canvas as it utilises shape clipping.\nTo remove a mask, set this property to null.

public.name: name
public.inlineHelp: The user defined name given to this Sprite.

public.name: outOfBoundsKill
public.inlineHelp: If true Sprite.kill is called as soon as Sprite.inWorld returns false, as long as Sprite.checkWorldBounds is true.

public.name: parent
public.help: [read-only] The display object container that contains this display object.

public.name: pivot
public.help: The pivot point of the displayObject that it rotates around

public.name: position
public.help: The coordinate of the object relative to the local coordinates of the parent.

public.name: renderOrderID
public.inlineHelp: The render order ID, reset every frame.

public.name: renderable
public.help: Can this object be rendered

public.name: rotation
public.help: The rotation of the object in radians.

public.name: scale
public.help: The scale factor of the object.

public.name: shader
public.help: The shader that will be used to render the texture to the stage. Set to null to remove a current shader.

public.name: smoothed
public.inlineHelp: Set to true to smooth the texture of this Sprite, or false to disable smoothing (great for pixel art)
public.help: Enable or disable texture smoothing for this Sprite. Only works for bitmap/image textures. Smoothing is enabled by default.

public.name: stage
public.help: [read-only] The stage the display object is connected to, or undefined if it is not connected to the stage.

public.name: texture
public.help: The texture that the sprite is using

public.name: tint
public.help: The tint applied to the sprite. This is a hex value. A value of 0xFFFFFF will remove any tint effect.

public.name: type
public.inlineHelp: The const type of this object.

public.name: visible
public.help: The visibility of the object.

public.name: width
public.help: The width of the sprite, setting this will actually modify the scale to achieve the value set

public.name: world
public.inlineHelp: The world coordinates of this Sprite. This differs from the x/y coordinates which are relative to the Sprites container.

public.name: worldAlpha
public.help: [read-only] The multiplied alpha of the displayObject

public.name: worldVisible
public.help: [read-only] Indicates if the sprite is globally visible.

public.name: x
public.inlineHelp: The position of the Sprite on the x axis relative to the local coordinates of the parent.
public.help: The position of the Sprite on the x axis relative to the local coordinates of the parent.

public.name: y
public.inlineHelp: The position of the Sprite on the y axis relative to the local coordinates of the parent.
public.help: The position of the Sprite on the y axis relative to the local coordinates of the parent.

public.name: z
public.inlineHelp: The z-depth value of this object within its Group (remember the World is a Group as well). No two objects in a Group can have the same z value.

private.name: _cache
private.help:
A small internal cache:

0 = previous position.x
1 = previous position.y
2 = previous rotation
3 = renderID
4 = fresh? (0 = no, 1 = yes)
5 = outOfBoundsFired (0 = no, 1 = yes)
6 = exists (0 = no, 1 = yes)
7 = fixed to camera (0 = no, 1 = yes)
8 = destroy phase? (0 = no, 1 = yes)

class.help:
Sprites are the lifeblood of your game, used for nearly everything visual.

At its most basic a Sprite consists of a set of coordinates and a texture that is rendered to the canvas.
They also contain additional properties allowing for physics motion (via Sprite.body), input handling (via Sprite.input),
events (via Sprite.events), animation (via Sprite.animations), camera culling and more. Please see the Examples for use cases.

parameters.name: game
parameters.help: A reference to the currently running game.

parameters.name: x
parameters.help: The x coordinate (in world space) to position the Sprite at.

parameters.name: y
parameters.help: The y coordinate (in world space) to position the Sprite at.

parameters.name: key
parameters.help: This is the image or texture used by the Sprite during rendering. It can be a string which is a reference to the Cache entry, or an instance of a RenderTexture or PIXI.Texture.

parameters.name: frame
parameters.help: If this Sprite is using part of a sprite sheet or texture atlas you can specify the exact frame to use by giving a string or numeric index.

class.name: Phaser.Sprite

public.name: addChild

parameters.name: child
parameters.help: The DisplayObject to add to the container

returns.help: The child that was added.

public.help: Adds a child to the container.

public.name: addChildAt

parameters.name: child
parameters.help: The child to add

parameters.name: index
parameters.help: The index to place the child in

returns.help: The child that was added.

public.help: Adds a child to the container at a specified index. If the index is out of bounds an error will be thrown

public.name: bringToTop
public.help: Brings the Sprite to the top of the display list it is a child of. Sprites that are members of a Phaser.Group are only\nbought to the top of that Group, not the entire display list.

public.name: click
public.help: A callback that is used when the users clicks on the displayObject with their mouse's left button

public.name: crop

parameters.name: rect
parameters.help: The Rectangle used during cropping. Pass null or no parameters to clear a previously set crop rectangle.

parameters.name: copy
parameters.help: If false Sprite.cropRect will be a reference to the given rect. If true it will copy the rect values into a local Sprite.cropRect object.

public.help:
Crop allows you to crop the texture used to display this Sprite.
This modifies the core Sprite texture frame, so the Sprite width/height properties will adjust accordingly.

Cropping takes place from the top-left of the Sprite and can be modified in real-time by either providing an updated rectangle object to Sprite.crop,
or by modifying Sprite.cropRect (or a reference to it) and then calling Sprite.updateCrop.

The rectangle object given to this method can be either a Phaser.Rectangle or any object so long as it has public x, y, width and height properties.
A reference to the rectangle is stored in Sprite.cropRect unless the `copy` parameter is `true` in which case the values are duplicated to a local object.

public.name: damage

parameters.name: amount
parameters.help: The amount to subtract from the Sprite.health value.

public.help: Damages the Sprite, this removes the given amount from the Sprites health property.\nIf health is then taken below or is equal to zero `Sprite.kill` is called.

public.name: destroy

parameters.name: destroyChildren
parameters.help: Should every child of this object have its destroy method called?

public.help: Destroys the Sprite. This removes it from its parent group, destroys the input, event and animation handlers if present\nand nulls its reference to game, freeing it up for garbage collection.

public.name: fromFrame

parameters.name: frameId
parameters.help: The frame Id of the texture in the cache

returns.help: A new Sprite using a texture from the texture cache matching the frameId

public.help: \nHelper function that creates a sprite that will contain a texture from the TextureCache based on the frameId\nThe frame ids are created when a Texture packer file has been loaded

public.name: fromImage

parameters.name: imageId
parameters.help: The image url of the texture

returns.help: A new Sprite using a texture from the texture cache matching the image id

public.help: \nHelper function that creates a sprite that will contain a texture based on an image url\nIf the image is not in the texture cache it will be loaded

parameters.name: resolution

parameters.name: scaleMode
parameters.help: Should be one of the PIXI.scaleMode consts

parameters.name: renderer
parameters.help: The renderer used to generate the texture.

returns.help: a texture of the graphics object

public.help: Useful function that returns a texture of the displayObject object that can then be used to create sprites\nThis can be quite useful if your displayObject is static / complicated and needs to be reused multiple times.

public.name: getBounds

parameters.name: matrix
parameters.help: the transformation matrix of the sprite

returns.help: the framing rectangle

public.help: Returns the bounds of the Sprite as a rectangle. The bounds calculation takes the worldTransform into account.

parameters.name: index

returns.help: The child at the given index, if any.

parameters.name: child

returns.help: The index position of the child display object to identify

public.help: Returns the index position of a child DisplayObject instance

public.name: getLocalBounds

returns.help: The rectangular bounding area

public.help: Retrieves the non-global local bounds of the displayObjectContainer as a rectangle. The calculation takes all visible children into consideration.

public.name: kill
public.help:
Kills a Sprite. A killed Sprite has its alive, exists and visible properties all set to false.
It will dispatch the onKilled event, you can listen to Sprite.events.onKilled for the signal.
Note that killing a Sprite is a way for you to quickly recycle it in a Sprite pool, it doesn't free it up from memory.
If you don't need this Sprite any more you should call Sprite.destroy instead.

public.name: loadTexture

parameters.name: key
parameters.help: This is the image or texture used by the Sprite during rendering. It can be a string which is a reference to the Cache entry, or an instance of a RenderTexture, BitmapData or PIXI.Texture.

parameters.name: frame
parameters.help: If this Sprite is using part of a sprite sheet or texture atlas you can specify the exact frame to use by giving a string or numeric index.

parameters.name: stopAnimation
parameters.help: If an animation is already playing on this Sprite you can choose to stop it or let it carry on playing.

public.help: Changes the Texture the Sprite is using entirely. The old texture is removed and the new one is referenced or fetched from the Cache.\nThis causes a WebGL texture update, so use sparingly or in low-intensity portions of your game.

public.name: mousedown
public.help: A callback that is used when the user clicks the mouse's left button down over the sprite

public.name: mouseout
public.help: A callback that is used when the users mouse leaves the displayObject

public.name: mouseover
public.help: A callback that is used when the users mouse rolls over the displayObject

public.name: mouseup
public.help: A callback that is used when the user releases the mouse's left button that was over the displayObject\nfor this callback to be fired, the mouse's left button must have been pressed down over the displayObject

public.name: mouseupoutside
public.help: A callback that is used when the user releases the mouse's left button that was over the displayObject but is no longer over the displayObject\nfor this callback to be fired, the mouse's left button must have been pressed down over the displayObject

public.name: overlap

parameters.name: displayObject
parameters.help: The display object to check against.

returns.help: True if the bounds of this Sprite intersects at any point with the bounds of the given display object.

public.help: Checks to see if the bounds of this Sprite overlaps with the bounds of the given Display Object, which can be a Sprite, Image, TileSprite or anything that extends those such as a Button.\nThis check ignores the Sprites hitArea property and runs a Sprite.getBounds comparison on both objects to determine the result.\nTherefore it's relatively expensive to use in large quantities (i.e. with lots of Sprites at a high frequency), but should be fine for low-volume testing where physics isn't required.

public.name: play

parameters.name: name
parameters.help: The name of the animation to be played, e.g. "fire", "walk", "jump".

parameters.name: frameRate
parameters.help: The framerate to play the animation at. The speed is given in frames per second. If not provided the previously set frameRate of the Animation is used.

parameters.name: loop
parameters.help: Should the animation be looped after playback. If not provided the previously set loop value of the Animation is used.

parameters.name: killOnComplete
parameters.help: If set to true when the animation completes (only happens if loop=false) the parent Sprite will be killed.

returns.help: A reference to playing Animation instance.

public.help: Play an animation based on the given key. The animation should previously have been added via sprite.animations.add()\nIf the requested animation is already playing this request will be ignored. If you need to reset an already running animation do so directly on the Animation object itself.

public.help: Resets the Sprite. This places the Sprite at the given x/y world coordinates and then\nsets alive, exists, visible and renderable all to true. Also resets the outOfBounds state and health values.\nIf the Sprite has a physics body that too is reset.

class.help:
A collection of methods for displaying debug information about game objects.
If your game is running in WebGL then Debug will create a Sprite that is placed at the top of the Stage display list and bind a canvas texture
to it, which must be uploaded every frame. Be advised: this is expenive.
If your game is using a Canvas renderer then the debug information is literally drawn on the top of the active game canvas and no Sprite is used.

parameters.help: A reference to the currently running game.

public.name: alpha
public.help: The opacity of the object.

public.name: angle
public.inlineHelp: Gets or sets the angle of rotation in degrees.
public.help: Indicates the rotation of the Graphics, in degrees, from its original orientation. Values from 0 to 180 represent clockwise rotation; values from 0 to -180 represent counterclockwise rotation.\nValues outside this range are added to or subtracted from 360 to obtain a value within the range. For example, the statement player.angle = 450 is the same as player.angle = 90.\nIf you wish to work in radians instead of degrees use the property Sprite.rotation instead.

public.name: blendMode
public.help: The blend mode to be applied to the graphic shape. Apply a value of PIXI.blendModes.NORMAL to reset the blend mode.

public.name: boundsPadding
public.help: The bounds' padding used for bounds calculation.

public.name: buttonMode
public.help: This is used to indicate if the displayObject should display a mouse hand cursor on rollover

public.name: cacheAsBitmap
public.help: Set if this display object is cached as a bitmap.\nThis basically takes a snap shot of the display object as it is at that moment. It can provide a performance benefit for complex static displayObjects.\nTo remove simply set this property to 'null'

public.name: cameraOffset
public.inlineHelp: If this object is fixedToCamera then this stores the x/y offset that its drawn at, from the top-left of the camera view.

public.name: children
public.help: [read-only] The array of children of this container.

public.name: defaultCursor
public.help: This is the cursor that will be used when the mouse is over this object. To enable this the element must have interaction = true and buttonMode = true\n

public.name: destroyPhase
public.inlineHelp: True if this object is currently being destroyed.

public.name: exists
public.inlineHelp: If exists = false then the Text isn't updated by the core game loop.

public.name: fillAlpha
public.help: The alpha value used when filling the Graphics object.

public.name: filterArea
public.help: The area the filter is applied to like the hitArea this is used as more of an optimisation\nrather than figuring out the dimensions of the displayObject each frame you can set this rectangle

public.name: filters
public.help: Sets the filters for the displayObject.\n* IMPORTANT: This is a webGL only feature and will be ignored by the canvas renderer.\nTo remove filters simply set this property to 'null'

public.name: fixedToCamera
public.inlineHelp: Set to true to fix this Graphics to the Camera at its current world coordinates.
public.help: An Graphics that is fixed to the camera uses its x/y coordinates as offsets from the top left of the camera. These are stored in Graphics.cameraOffset.\nNote that the cameraOffset values are in addition to any parent in the display list.\nSo if this Graphics was in a Group that has x: 200, then this will be added to the cameraOffset.x

public.name: game
public.inlineHelp: A reference to the currently running Game.

public.name: height
public.help: The height of the displayObjectContainer, setting this will actually modify the scale to achieve the value set

public.name: hitArea
public.help: This is the defined area that will pick up mouse / touch events. It is null by default.\nSetting it is a neat way of optimising the hitTest function that the interactionManager will use (as it will not need to hit test all the children)

public.name: interactive
public.help: Indicates if the sprite will have touch and mouse interactivity. It is false by default

public.name: isMask
public.help: Whether this shape is being used as a mask.

public.name: lineColor
public.help: The color of any lines drawn.

public.name: lineWidth
public.help: The width (thickness) of any lines drawn.

public.name: mask
public.help: Sets a mask for the displayObject. A mask is an object that limits the visibility of an object to the shape of the mask applied to it.\nIn PIXI a regular mask must be a PIXI.Graphics object. This allows for much faster masking in canvas as it utilises shape clipping.\nTo remove a mask, set this property to null.

public.name: name
public.inlineHelp: The user defined name given to this object.

public.name: parent
public.help: [read-only] The display object container that contains this display object.

public.name: pivot
public.help: The pivot point of the displayObject that it rotates around

public.name: position
public.help: The coordinate of the object relative to the local coordinates of the parent.

public.name: renderable
public.help: Can this object be rendered

public.name: rotation
public.help: The rotation of the object in radians.

public.name: scale
public.help: The scale factor of the object.

public.name: stage
public.help: [read-only] The stage the display object is connected to, or undefined if it is not connected to the stage.

public.name: tint
public.help: The tint applied to the graphic shape. This is a hex value. Apply a value of 0xFFFFFF to reset the tint.

public.name: type
public.inlineHelp: The const type of this object.

public.name: visible
public.help: The visibility of the object.

public.name: width
public.help: The width of the displayObjectContainer, setting this will actually modify the scale to achieve the value set

public.name: world
public.inlineHelp: The world coordinates of this Sprite. This differs from the x/y coordinates which are relative to the Sprites container.

public.name: worldAlpha
public.help: [read-only] The multiplied alpha of the displayObject

public.name: worldVisible
public.help: [read-only] Indicates if the sprite is globally visible.

public.name: x
public.help: The position of the displayObject on the x axis relative to the local coordinates of the parent.

public.name: y
public.help: The position of the displayObject on the y axis relative to the local coordinates of the parent.

public.name: z
public.inlineHelp: The z-depth value of this object within its Group (remember the World is a Group as well). No two objects in a Group can have the same z value.

private.name: _cache
private.help:
A small internal cache:
0 = previous position.x
1 = previous position.y
2 = previous rotation
3 = renderID
4 = fresh? (0 = no, 1 = yes)
5 = outOfBoundsFired (0 = no, 1 = yes)
6 = exists (0 = no, 1 = yes)
7 = fixed to camera (0 = no, 1 = yes)
8 = destroy phase? (0 = no, 1 = yes)

parameters.name: rgba
parameters.help: The integer, packed in endian order by packPixel.

parameters.name: out
parameters.help: An object into which 3 properties will be created: r, g and b. If not provided a new object will be created.

parameters.name: hsl
parameters.help: Also convert the rgb values into hsl?

parameters.name: hsv
parameters.help: Also convert the rgb values into hsv?

returns.help: An object with the red, green and blue values set in the r, g and b properties.

public.help:
Unpacks the r, g, b, a components into the specified color object, or a new
object, for use with Int32Array. If little endian, then ABGR order is used when
unpacking, otherwise, RGBA order is used. The resulting color object has the
`r, g, b, a` properties which are unrelated to endianness.

Note that the integer is assumed to be packed in the correct endianness. On little-endian
the format is 0xAABBGGRR and on big-endian the format is 0xRRGGBBAA. If you want a
endian-independent method, use fromRGBA(rgba) and toRGBA(r, g, b, a).

class.help: The Animation Manager is used to add, play and update Phaser Animations.\nAny Game Object such as Phaser.Sprite that supports animation contains a single AnimationManager instance.

parameters.help: A reference to the Game Object that owns this AnimationManager.

parameters.help: The unique (within this Sprite) name for the animation, i.e. "run", "fire", "walk".

parameters.name: frames

parameters.name: frameRate
parameters.help: The speed at which the animation should play. The speed is given in frames per second.

parameters.name: loop
parameters.help: Whether or not the animation is looped or just plays once.

parameters.name: useNumericIndex
parameters.help: Are the given frames using numeric indexes (default) or strings?

returns.help: The Animation object that was created.

public.help: Adds a new animation under the given key. Optionally set the frames, frame rate and loop.\nAnimations added in this way are played back with the play function.

public.name: destroy
public.help: Destroys all references this AnimationManager contains.\nIterates through the list of animations stored in this manager and calls destroy on each of them.

public.name: play

parameters.help: The name of the animation to be played, e.g. "fire", "walk", "jump".

parameters.name: frameRate
parameters.help: The framerate to play the animation at. The speed is given in frames per second. If not provided the previously set frameRate of the Animation is used.

parameters.name: loop
parameters.help: Should the animation be looped after playback. If not provided the previously set loop value of the Animation is used.

parameters.name: killOnComplete
parameters.help: If set to true when the animation completes (only happens if loop=false) the parent Sprite will be killed.

returns.help: A reference to playing Animation instance.

public.help: Play an animation based on the given key. The animation should previously have been added via sprite.animations.add()\nIf the requested animation is already playing this request will be ignored. If you need to reset an already running animation do so directly on the Animation object itself.

Sets the Image Smoothing property on the given context. Set to false to disable image smoothing.
By default browsers have image smoothing enabled, which isn't always what you visually want, especially
when using pixel art in a game. Note that this sets the property on the context itself, so that any image
drawn to the context will be affected. This sets the property across all current browsers but support is
patchy on earlier browsers, especially on mobile.

class.help:
The Spine loader is used to load in JSON spine data
To generate the data you need to use http://esotericsoftware.com/ and export in the "JSON" format
Due to a clash of names  You will need to change the extension of the spine file from *.json to *.anim for it to load
See example 12 (http://www.goodboydigital.com/pixijs/examples/12/) to see a working example and check out the source
You will need to generate a sprite sheet to accompany the spine data
When loaded this class will dispatch a "loaded" event

class.help:
The ConvolutionFilter class applies a matrix convolution filter effect.
A convolution combines pixels in the input image with neighboring pixels to produce a new image.
A wide variety of image effects can be achieved through convolutions, including blurring, edge detection, sharpening, embossing, and beveling.
The matrix should be specified as a 9 point Array. See http://docs.gimp.org/en/plug-in-convmatrix.html for more info.
