public.name: addColor

parameters.name: color
parameters.help: A canvas fillstyle that will be used on the text eg `red`, `#00FF00`, `rgba()`.

parameters.name: position
parameters.help: The index of the character in the string to start applying this color value from.

public.help:
This method allows you to set specific colors within the Text.
It works by taking a color value, which is a typical HTML string such as `#ff0000` or `rgb(255,0,0)` and a position.
The position value is the index of the character in the Text string to start applying this color to.
Once set the color remains in use until either another color or the end of the string is encountered.
For example if the Text was `Photon Storm` and you did `Text.addColor('#ffff00', 6)` it would color in the word `Storm` in yellow.

public.help: If Signal should keep record of previously dispatched parameters and\nautomatically execute listener during `add()`/`addOnce()` if Signal was\nalready dispatched before.

class.help: A Signal is used for object communication via a custom broadcaster instead of Events.
class.name: Phaser.Signal

parameters.name: listenerContext

parameters.name: priority
parameters.help: The priority level of the event listener. Listeners with higher priority will be executed before listeners with lower priority. Listeners with same priority level will be executed at the same order as they were added (default = 0)

returns.help: An Object representing the binding between the Signal and listener.

returns.help: An Object representing the binding between the Signal and listener.

public.help: Add listener to the signal that should be removed after first execution (will be executed only once).

public.name: dispatch

public.help: Dispatch/Broadcast Signal to all listeners added to the queue.

public.name: dispose
public.help: Remove all bindings from signal and destroy any reference to external objects (destroy Signal object).\nIMPORTANT: calling any method on the signal instance after calling dispose will throw errors.

public.name: halt
public.help: Stop propagation of the event, blocking the dispatch to next listeners on the queue.\nIMPORTANT: should be called only during signal dispatch, calling it before/after dispatch won't affect signal broadcast.

public.name: alive
public.inlineHelp: A useful boolean to control if the TileSprite is alive or dead (in terms of your gameplay, it doesn't effect rendering).

public.name: alpha
public.help: The opacity of the object.

public.name: anchor
public.help:
The anchor sets the origin point of the texture.
The default is 0,0 this means the texture's origin is the top left
Setting than anchor to 0.5,0.5 means the textures origin is centered
Setting the anchor to 1,1 would mean the textures origin points will be the bottom right corner

public.name: angle
public.inlineHelp: The angle of this Sprite in degrees.
public.help: Indicates the rotation of the Sprite, in degrees, from its original orientation. Values from 0 to 180 represent clockwise rotation; values from 0 to -180 represent counterclockwise rotation.\nValues outside this range are added to or subtracted from 360 to obtain a value within the range. For example, the statement player.angle = 450 is the same as player.angle = 90.\nIf you wish to work in radians instead of degrees use the property Sprite.rotation instead. Working in radians is also a little faster as it doesn't have to convert the angle.

public.name: animations
public.inlineHelp: This manages animations of the sprite. You can modify animations through it (see Phaser.AnimationManager)

public.name: autoCull
public.inlineHelp: A flag indicating if the Sprite should be automatically camera culled or not.
public.help: Should this Sprite be automatically culled if out of range of the camera?\nA culled sprite has its renderable property set to 'false'.\nBe advised this is quite an expensive operation, as it has to calculate the bounds of the object every frame, so only enable it if you really need it.

public.name: blendMode
public.help: The blend mode to be applied to the sprite

public.name: body
public.help:
By default Sprites won't add themselves to any physics system and their physics body will be `null`.
To enable them for physics you need to call `game.physics.enable(sprite, system)` where `sprite` is this object
and `system` is the Physics system you want to use to manage this body. Once enabled you can access all physics related properties via `Sprite.body`.

Important: Enabling a Sprite for P2 or Ninja physics will automatically set `Sprite.anchor` to 0.5 so the physics body is centered on the Sprite.
If you need a different result then adjust or re-create the Body shape offsets manually, and/or reset the anchor after enabling physics.

public.name: buttonMode
public.help: This is used to indicate if the displayObject should display a mouse hand cursor on rollover

public.name: cacheAsBitmap
public.help: Set if this display object is cached as a bitmap.\nThis basically takes a snap shot of the display object as it is at that moment. It can provide a performance benefit for complex static displayObjects.\nTo remove simply set this property to 'null'

public.name: cameraOffset
public.inlineHelp: If this object is fixedToCamera then this stores the x/y offset that its drawn at, from the top-left of the camera view.

public.name: checkWorldBounds
public.help: If true the Sprite checks if it is still within the world each frame, when it leaves the world it dispatches Sprite.events.onOutOfBounds\nand optionally kills the sprite (if Sprite.outOfBoundsKill is true). By default this is disabled because the Sprite has to calculate its\nbounds every frame to support it, and not all games need it. Enable it by setting the value to true.

public.name: children
public.help: [read-only] The array of children of this container.

public.name: defaultCursor
public.help: This is the cursor that will be used when the mouse is over this object. To enable this the element must have interaction = true and buttonMode = true\n

public.name: destroyPhase
public.inlineHelp: True if this object is currently being destroyed.

public.name: events
public.inlineHelp: The Events you can subscribe to that are dispatched when certain things happen on this Sprite or its components.

public.name: exists
public.inlineHelp: If the TileSprite is processed by the core game update and physics.
public.help: TileSprite.exists controls if the core game loop and physics update this TileSprite or not.\nWhen you set TileSprite.exists to false it will remove its Body from the physics world (if it has one) and also set TileSprite.visible to false.\nSetting TileSprite.exists to true will re-add the Body to the physics world (if it has a body) and set TileSprite.visible to true.

public.name: filterArea
public.help: The area the filter is applied to like the hitArea this is used as more of an optimisation\nrather than figuring out the dimensions of the displayObject each frame you can set this rectangle

public.name: filters
public.help: Sets the filters for the displayObject.\n* IMPORTANT: This is a webGL only feature and will be ignored by the canvas renderer.\nTo remove filters simply set this property to 'null'

public.name: fixedToCamera
public.inlineHelp: Set to true to fix this TileSprite to the Camera at its current world coordinates.
public.help: An TileSprite that is fixed to the camera uses its x/y coordinates as offsets from the top left of the camera. These are stored in TileSprite.cameraOffset.\nNote that the cameraOffset values are in addition to any parent in the display list.\nSo if this TileSprite was in a Group that has x: 200, then this will be added to the cameraOffset.x

public.name: frame
public.inlineHelp: Gets or sets the current frame index and updates the Texture Cache for display.

public.name: frameName
public.inlineHelp: Gets or sets the current frame name and updates the Texture Cache for display.

public.name: game
public.inlineHelp: A reference to the currently running Game.

public.name: height
public.help: The height of the TilingSprite, setting this will actually modify the scale to achieve the value set

public.name: hitArea
public.help: This is the defined area that will pick up mouse / touch events. It is null by default.\nSetting it is a neat way of optimising the hitTest function that the interactionManager will use (as it will not need to hit test all the children)

public.name: input
public.inlineHelp: The Input Handler for this object. Needs to be enabled with image.inputEnabled = true before you can use it.

public.name: inputEnabled
public.inlineHelp: Set to true to allow this object to receive input events.
public.help: By default a TileSprite won't process any input events at all. By setting inputEnabled to true the Phaser.InputHandler is\nactivated for this object and it will then start to process click/touch events and more.

public.name: interactive
public.help: Indicates if the sprite will have touch and mouse interactivity. It is false by default

public.name: key
public.inlineHelp: This is the image or texture used by the Sprite during rendering. It can be a string which is a reference to the Cache entry, or an instance of a RenderTexture, BitmapData or PIXI.Texture.

public.name: mask
public.help: Sets a mask for the displayObject. A mask is an object that limits the visibility of an object to the shape of the mask applied to it.\nIn PIXI a regular mask must be a PIXI.Graphics object. This allows for much faster masking in canvas as it utilises shape clipping.\nTo remove a mask, set this property to null.

public.name: name
public.inlineHelp: The user defined name given to this Sprite.

public.name: parent
public.help: [read-only] The display object container that contains this display object.

public.name: pivot
public.help: The pivot point of the displayObject that it rotates around

public.name: position
public.help: The coordinate of the object relative to the local coordinates of the parent.

public.name: renderable
public.help: Whether this sprite is renderable or not

public.name: rotation
public.help: The rotation of the object in radians.

public.name: scale
public.help: The scale factor of the object.

public.name: shader
public.help: The shader that will be used to render the texture to the stage. Set to null to remove a current shader.

public.name: stage
public.help: [read-only] The stage the display object is connected to, or undefined if it is not connected to the stage.

public.name: texture
public.help: The texture that the sprite is using

public.name: tilePosition
public.help: The offset position of the image that is being tiled

public.name: tileScale
public.help: The scaling of the image that is being tiled

public.name: tileScaleOffset
public.help: A point that represents the scale of the texture object

public.name: tint
public.help: The tint applied to the sprite. This is a hex value

public.name: type
public.inlineHelp: The const type of this object.

public.name: visible
public.help: The visibility of the object.

public.name: width
public.help: The width of the sprite, setting this will actually modify the scale to achieve the value set

public.name: world
public.inlineHelp: The world coordinates of this Sprite. This differs from the x/y coordinates which are relative to the Sprites container.

public.name: worldAlpha
public.help: [read-only] The multiplied alpha of the displayObject

public.name: worldVisible
public.help: [read-only] Indicates if the sprite is globally visible.

public.name: x
public.inlineHelp: The position of the TileSprite on the x axis relative to the local coordinates of the parent.
public.help: The position of the TileSprite on the x axis relative to the local coordinates of the parent.

public.name: y
public.inlineHelp: The position of the TileSprite on the y axis relative to the local coordinates of the parent.
public.help: The position of the TileSprite on the y axis relative to the local coordinates of the parent.

public.name: z
public.inlineHelp: The z-depth value of this object within its Group (remember the World is a Group as well). No two objects in a Group can have the same z value.

private.name: _cache
private.help:
A small internal cache:
0 = previous position.x
1 = previous position.y
2 = previous rotation
3 = renderID
4 = fresh? (0 = no, 1 = yes)
5 = outOfBoundsFired (0 = no, 1 = yes)
6 = exists (0 = no, 1 = yes)
7 = fixed to camera (0 = no, 1 = yes)
8 = destroy phase? (0 = no, 1 = yes)

class.help: A TileSprite is a Sprite that has a repeating texture. The texture can be scrolled and scaled and will automatically wrap on the edges as it does so.\nPlease note that TileSprites, as with normal Sprites, have no input handler or physics bodies by default. Both need enabling.

parameters.name: game
parameters.help: A reference to the currently running game.

parameters.name: x
parameters.help: The x coordinate (in world space) to position the TileSprite at.

parameters.name: y
parameters.help: The y coordinate (in world space) to position the TileSprite at.

parameters.name: width
parameters.help: The width of the TileSprite.

parameters.name: height
parameters.help: The height of the TileSprite.

parameters.name: key
parameters.help: This is the image or texture used by the TileSprite during rendering. It can be a string which is a reference to the Cache entry, or an instance of a RenderTexture or PIXI.Texture.

parameters.name: frame
parameters.help: If this TileSprite is using part of a sprite sheet or texture atlas you can specify the exact frame to use by giving a string or numeric index.

public.help:
Sets this TileSprite to automatically scroll in the given direction until stopped via TileSprite.stopScroll().
The scroll speed is specified in pixels per second.
A negative x value will scroll to the left. A positive x value will scroll to the right.
A negative y value will scroll up. A positive y value will scroll down.

public.name: mousedown

public.name: mouseout

public.name: mouseover

public.name: mouseup

public.name: mouseupoutside
public.help: A callback that is used when the user releases the mouse's left button that was over the displayObject but is no longer over the displayObject\nfor this callback to be fired, the mouse's left button must have been pressed down over the displayObject

parameters.name: frameRate

parameters.name: loop
parameters.help: Should the animation be looped after playback. If not provided the previously set loop value of the Animation is used.

parameters.name: killOnComplete
parameters.help: If set to true when the animation completes (only happens if loop=false) the parent Sprite will be killed.

returns.help: A reference to playing Animation instance.

public.help: Play an animation based on the given key. The animation should previously have been added via sprite.animations.add()\nIf the requested animation is already playing this request will be ignored. If you need to reset an already running animation do so directly on the Animation object itself.

public.name: disabled
public.inlineHelp: You can disable all Input by setting disabled = true. While set all new input related events will be ignored.

public.name: event
public.inlineHelp: The browser mouse DOM event. Will be set to null if no mouse event has ever been received.

public.name: game

public.name: locked

public.name: mouseMoveCallback

public.name: mouseOutCallback
public.inlineHelp: A callback that can be fired when the mouse is no longer over the game canvas.

public.name: mouseOverCallback
public.inlineHelp: A callback that can be fired when the mouse enters the game canvas (usually after a mouseout).

public.name: mouseUpCallback

public.name: mouseWheelCallback
public.inlineHelp: A callback that can be fired when the mousewheel is used.

public.name: pointerLock
public.inlineHelp: This event is dispatched when the browser enters or leaves pointer lock state.

public.name: stopOnGameOut
public.inlineHelp: If true Pointer.stop will be called if the mouse leaves the game canvas.

public.name: wheelDelta
public.inlineHelp: The direction of the mousewheel usage 1 for up -1 for down

class.help: Phaser.Mouse is responsible for handling all aspects of mouse interaction with the browser.\nIt captures and processes mouse events that happen on the game canvas object. It also adds a single `mouseup` listener to `window` which\nis used to capture the mouse being released when not over the game.

public.name: requestPointerLock
public.help: If the browser supports it you can request that the pointer be locked to the browser window.\nThis is classically known as 'FPS controls', where the pointer can't leave the browser until the user presses an exit key.\nIf the browser successfully enters a locked state the event Phaser.Mouse.pointerLock will be dispatched and the first parameter will be 'true'.

public.name: cameraOffset
public.inlineHelp: If this object is fixed to the camera then use this Point to specify how far away from the Camera x/y it's rendered.

public.name: canvas
public.inlineHelp: The canvas to which this TilemapLayer draws.

public.name: collisionHeight
public.inlineHelp: The height of the collision tiles.

public.name: collisionWidth
public.inlineHelp: The width of the collision tiles.

public.name: context
public.inlineHelp: The 2d context of the canvas.

public.name: debug
public.inlineHelp: If set to true the collideable tile edges path will be rendered. Only works when game is running in Phaser.CANVAS mode.

public.name: debugAlpha
public.inlineHelp: If debug is true then the tileset is rendered with this alpha level, to make the tile edges clearer.

public.name: debugCallbackColor
public.inlineHelp: If debug is true this is the color used to outline the edges of tiles that have collision callbacks. Provide in hex or rgb/rgba string format.

public.name: debugColor
public.inlineHelp: If debug is true this is the color used to outline the edges of collidable tiles. Provide in hex or rgb/rgba string format.

public.name: debugFill
public.inlineHelp: If true the debug tiles are filled with debugFillColor AND stroked around.

public.name: debugFillColor
public.inlineHelp: If debugFill is true this is the color used to fill the tiles. Provide in hex or rgb/rgba string format.

public.name: dirty
public.inlineHelp: Flag controlling when to re-render the layer.

public.name: fixedToCamera
public.inlineHelp: Fixes this object to the Camera.
public.help: An object that is fixed to the camera ignores the position of any ancestors in the display list and uses its x/y coordinates as offsets from the top left of the camera.

public.name: game
public.inlineHelp: A reference to the currently running Game.

public.name: index
public.inlineHelp: The index of this layer within the Tilemap.

public.name: layer
public.inlineHelp: The layer object within the Tilemap that this layer represents.

public.name: map
public.inlineHelp: The Tilemap to which this layer is bound.

public.name: name
public.inlineHelp: The name of the layer.

public.name: rayStepRate
public.inlineHelp: When ray-casting against tiles this is the number of steps it will jump. For larger tile sizes you can increase this to improve performance.

public.name: scrollFactorX
public.inlineHelp: speed at which this layer scrolls
public.help: horizontally, relative to the camera (e.g. scrollFactorX of 0.5 scrolls\nhalf as quickly as the 'normal' camera-locked layers do)

public.name: scrollFactorY
public.inlineHelp: speed at which this layer scrolls
public.help: vertically, relative to the camera (e.g. scrollFactorY of 0.5 scrolls\nhalf as quickly as the 'normal' camera-locked layers do)

public.name: scrollX
public.inlineHelp: Scrolls the map horizontally or returns the current x position.

public.name: scrollY
public.inlineHelp: Scrolls the map vertically or returns the current y position.

public.name: texture
public.inlineHelp: Required Pixi var.

public.name: textureFrame
public.inlineHelp: Dimensions of the renderable area.

public.name: tileColor
public.inlineHelp: If no tileset is given the tiles will be rendered as rectangles in this color. Provide in hex or rgb/rgba string format.

public.name: type
public.inlineHelp: The const type of this object.

public.name: wrap
public.inlineHelp: Flag controlling if the layer tiles wrap at the edges. Only works if the World size matches the Map size.

private.name: _mc
private.inlineHelp: Local map data and calculation cache.

private.name: _results
private.inlineHelp: Local render loop var to help avoid gc spikes.

This allows for much faster masking in canvas as it utilises shape clipping.\nTo remove a mask, set this property to null.

public.name: diameter
public.inlineHelp: Gets or sets the diameter of the circle.
public.help: The largest distance between any two points on the circle. The same as the radius * 2.

public.name: empty
public.inlineHelp: Gets or sets the empty state of the circle.
public.help: Determines whether or not this Circle object is empty. Will return a value of true if the Circle objects diameter is less than or equal to 0; otherwise false.\nIf set to true it will reset all of the Circle objects properties to 0. A Circle object is empty if its diameter is less than or equal to 0.

public.name: radius
public.inlineHelp: Gets or sets the radius of the circle.
public.help: The length of a line extending from the center of the circle to any point on the circle itself. The same as half the diameter.

public.name: right
public.inlineHelp: Gets or sets the value of the rightmost point of the circle.
public.help: The x coordinate of the rightmost point of the circle. Changing the right property of a Circle object has no effect on the x and y properties. However it does affect the diameter, whereas changing the x value does not affect the diameter property.

public.name: top
public.inlineHelp: Gets or sets the top of the circle.
public.help: The sum of the y minus the radius property. Changing the top property of a Circle object has no effect on the x and y properties, but does change the diameter.

public.name: x
public.inlineHelp: The x coordinate of the center of the circle.

public.name: y
public.inlineHelp: The y coordinate of the center of the circle.

class.help:
Creates a new Polygon. You have to provide a list of points.
This can be an array of Points that form the polygon, a flat array of numbers that will be interpreted as [x,y, x,y, ...],
or the arguments passed can be all the points of the polygon e.g. `new Phaser.Polygon(new Phaser.Point(), new Phaser.Point(), ...)`, or the
arguments passed can be flat x,y values e.g. `new Phaser.Polygon(x,y, x,y, x,y, ...)` where `x` and `y` are numbers.

protected.inlineHelp: The time the previous update occurred.

public.name: advancedTiming
public.inlineHelp: If true Phaser.Time will perform advanced profiling including the fps rate, fps min/max and msMin and msMax.

public.name: deltaCap
public.inlineHelp: If you need to cap the delta timer, set the value here. For 60fps the delta should be 0.016, so try variances just above this.

public.name: events
public.inlineHelp: This is a Phaser.Timer object bound to the master clock to which you can add timed events.

public.name: fpsMax
public.inlineHelp: The highest rate the fps has reached (usually no higher than 60fps). Only calculated if Time.advancedTiming is true.

public.name: fpsMin
public.inlineHelp: The lowest rate the fps has dropped to. Only calculated if Time.advancedTiming is true.

public.name: frames
public.inlineHelp: The number of frames record in the last second. Only calculated if Time.advancedTiming is true.

public.name: game
public.inlineHelp: Local reference to game.

public.name: lastTime
public.inlineHelp: Internal value used by timeToCall as part of the setTimeout loop

public.name: msMax
public.inlineHelp: The maximum amount of time the game has taken between two frames. Only calculated if Time.advancedTiming is true.

public.name: msMin
public.inlineHelp: The minimum amount of time the game has taken between two frames. Only calculated if Time.advancedTiming is true.

public.name: pauseDuration
public.inlineHelp: Records how long the game was paused for in miliseconds.

public.name: physicsElapsed
public.inlineHelp: The elapsed time calculated for the physics motion updates. In a stable 60fps system this will be 0.016 every frame.

public.name: timeCap
public.inlineHelp: If the difference in time between two frame updates exceeds this value, the frame time is reset to avoid huge elapsed counts.

public.name: timeToCall
public.inlineHelp: The value that setTimeout needs to work out when to next update

private.name: _justResumed
private.inlineHelp: Internal value used to recover from the game pause state.

private.name: _pauseStarted
private.inlineHelp: The time the game started being paused.

private.name: _started
private.inlineHelp: The time at which the Game instance started.

private.name: _timeLastSecond
private.inlineHelp: The time (in ms) that the last second counter ticked over.

Generate a sine and cosine table simultaneously and extremely quickly. Based on research by Franky of scene.at

This allows for much faster masking in canvas as it utilises shape clipping.\nTo remove a mask, set this property to null.

class.help: A BitmapData object contains a Canvas element to which you can draw anything you like via normal Canvas context operations.\nA single BitmapData can be used as the texture for one or many Images/Sprites.\nSo if you need to dynamically create a Sprite texture then they are a good choice.

parameters.help: The height of the BitmapData in pixels.

public.name: copy

parameters.name: source
parameters.help: The source to copy from. If you give a string it will try and find the Image in the Game.Cache first. This is quite expensive so try to provide the image itself.

parameters.name: x
parameters.help: The x coordinate representing the top-left of the region to copy from the source image.

parameters.name: y
parameters.help: The y coordinate representing the top-left of the region to copy from the source image.

parameters.name: width
parameters.help: The width of the region to copy from the source image. If not specified it will use the full source image width.

parameters.name: height
parameters.help: The height of the region to copy from the source image. If not specified it will use the full source image height.

parameters.name: tx
parameters.help: The x coordinate to translate to before drawing. If not specified it will default to the `x` parameter.

parameters.name: ty
parameters.help: The y coordinate to translate to before drawing. If not specified it will default to the `y` parameter.

parameters.name: newWidth
parameters.help: The new width of the block being copied. If not specified it will default to the `width` parameter.

parameters.name: newHeight
parameters.help: The new height of the block being copied. If not specified it will default to the `height` parameter.

parameters.name: rotate
parameters.help: The angle in radians to rotate the block to before drawing. Rotation takes place around the center by default, but can be changed with the `anchor` parameters.

parameters.name: anchorX
parameters.help: The anchor point around which the block is rotated and scaled. A value between 0 and 1, where 0 is the top-left and 1 is bottom-right.

parameters.name: anchorY
parameters.help: The anchor point around which the block is rotated and scaled. A value between 0 and 1, where 0 is the top-left and 1 is bottom-right.

parameters.name: scaleX
parameters.help: The horizontal scale factor of the block. A value of 1 means no scaling. 2 would be twice the size, and so on.

parameters.name: scaleY
parameters.help: The vertical scale factor of the block. A value of 1 means no scaling. 2 would be twice the size, and so on.

parameters.name: alpha
parameters.help: The alpha that will be set on the context before drawing. A value between 0 (fully transparent) and 1, opaque.

parameters.name: blendMode
parameters.help: The composite blend mode that will be used when drawing. The default is no blend mode at all.

parameters.name: roundPx
parameters.help: Should the x and y values be rounded to integers before drawing? This prevents anti-aliasing in some instances.

returns.help: This BitmapData object for method chaining.

public.help:
Copies a rectangular area from the source object to this BitmapData. If you give `null` as the source it will copy from itself.
You can optionally resize, translate, rotate, scale, alpha or blend as it's drawn.
All rotation, scaling and drawing takes place around the regions center point by default, but can be changed with the anchor parameters.
Note that the source image can also be this BitmapData, which can create some interesting effects.

This method has a lot of parameters for maximum control.
You can use the more friendly methods like `copyRect` and `draw` to avoid having to remember them all.

public.name: copyRect

parameters.name: source
parameters.help: The Image to copy from. If you give a string it will try and find the Image in the Game.Cache.

parameters.name: area
parameters.help: The Rectangle region to copy from the source image.

parameters.name: x
parameters.help: The destination x coordinate to copy the image to.

parameters.name: y
parameters.help: The destination y coordinate to copy the image to.

parameters.name: alpha
parameters.help: The alpha that will be set on the context before drawing. A value between 0 (fully transparent) and 1, opaque.

parameters.name: blendMode
parameters.help: The composite blend mode that will be used when drawing. The default is no blend mode at all.

parameters.name: roundPx
parameters.help: Should the x and y values be rounded to integers before drawing? This prevents anti-aliasing in some instances.

returns.help: This BitmapData object for method chaining.

public.help: Copies the area defined by the Rectangle parameter from the source image to this BitmapData at the given location.

public.name: draw

parameters.name: source
parameters.help: The Sprite, Image or Text object to draw onto this BitmapData.

parameters.name: x
parameters.help: The x coordinate to translate to before drawing. If not specified it will default to `source.x`.

parameters.name: y
parameters.help: The y coordinate to translate to before drawing. If not specified it will default to `source.y`.

parameters.name: width
parameters.help: The new width of the Sprite being copied. If not specified it will default to `source.width`.

parameters.name: height
parameters.help: The new height of the Sprite being copied. If not specified it will default to `source.height`.

parameters.name: blendMode
parameters.help: The composite blend mode that will be used when drawing the Sprite. The default is no blend mode at all.

parameters.name: roundPx
parameters.help: Should the x and y values be rounded to integers before drawing? This prevents anti-aliasing in some instances.

returns.help: This BitmapData object for method chaining.

public.help: Draws the given Phaser.Sprite, Phaser.Image or Phaser.Text to this BitmapData at the coordinates specified.\nYou can use the optional width and height values to 'stretch' the sprite as it is drawn. This uses drawImage stretching, not scaling.\nWhen drawing it will take into account the Sprites rotation, scale and alpha values.

public.name: extract

parameters.name: destination
parameters.help: The BitmapData that the extracted pixels will be drawn to.

parameters.name: r
parameters.help: The red color component, in the range 0 - 255.

parameters.name: g
parameters.help: The green color component, in the range 0 - 255.

parameters.name: b
parameters.help: The blue color component, in the range 0 - 255.

parameters.name: a
parameters.help: The alpha color component, in the range 0 - 255 that the new pixel will be drawn at.

parameters.name: resize
parameters.help: Should the destination BitmapData be resized to match this one before the pixels are copied?

parameters.name: r2
parameters.help: An alternative red color component to be written to the destination, in the range 0 - 255.

parameters.name: g2
parameters.help: An alternative green color component to be written to the destination, in the range 0 - 255.

parameters.name: b2
parameters.help: An alternative blue color component to be written to the destination, in the range 0 - 255.

public.help:
Scans this BitmapData for all pixels matching the given r,g,b values and then draws them into the given destination BitmapData.
The original BitmapData remains unchanged.
The destination BitmapData must be large enough to receive all of the pixels that are scanned unless the 'resize' parameter is true.
Although the destination BitmapData is returned from this method, it's actually modified directly in place, meaning this call is perfectly valid:
`picture.extract(mask, r, g, b)`
You can specify optional r2, g2, b2 color values. If given the pixel written to the destination bitmap will be of the r2, g2, b2 color.
If not given it will be written as the same color it was extracted. You can provide one or more alternative colors, allowing you to tint
the color during extraction.

public.name: fill

parameters.name: r
parameters.help: The red color value, between 0 and 0xFF (255).

parameters.name: g
parameters.help: The green color value, between 0 and 0xFF (255).

parameters.name: b
parameters.help: The blue color value, between 0 and 0xFF (255).

parameters.name: a
parameters.help: The alpha color value, between 0 and 1.

returns.help: This BitmapData object for method chaining.

public.help: Fills the BitmapData with the given color.

public.name: getBounds

parameters.name: rect
parameters.help: If provided this Rectangle object will be populated with the bounds, otherwise a new object will be created.

returns.help: A Rectangle whose dimensions encompass the full extent of non-transparent pixels in this BitmapData.

public.help: Scans the BitmapData and calculates the bounds. This is a rectangle that defines the extent of all non-transparent pixels.\nThe rectangle returned will extend from the top-left of the image to the bottom-right, exluding transparent pixels.

public.name: getFirstPixel

parameters.name: direction
parameters.help: The direction in which to scan for the first pixel. 0 = top to bottom, 1 = bottom to top, 2 = left to right and 3 = right to left.

returns.help: Returns an object containing the colour of the pixel in the `r`, `g` and `b` properties and the location in the `x` and `y` properties.

public.help:
Scans the BitmapData, pixel by pixel, until it encounters a pixel that isn't transparent (i.e. has an alpha value > 0).
It then stops scanning and returns an object containing the colour of the pixel in r, g and b properties and the location in the x and y properties.

The direction parameter controls from which direction it should start the scan:

0 = top to bottom
1 = bottom to top
2 = left to right
3 = right to left

public.name: getPixel

parameters.name: x
parameters.help: The x coordinate of the pixel to be set. Must lay within the dimensions of this BitmapData.

parameters.name: y
parameters.help: The y coordinate of the pixel to be set. Must lay within the dimensions of this BitmapData.

parameters.name: out
parameters.help: An object into which 4 properties will be created: r, g, b and a. If not provided a new object will be created.

returns.help: An object with the red, green, blue and alpha values set in the r, g, b and a properties.

public.help: Get the color of a specific pixel in the context into a color object.\nIf you have drawn anything to the BitmapData since it was created you must call BitmapData.update to refresh the array buffer,\notherwise this may return out of date color values, or worse - throw a run-time error as it tries to access an array element that doesn't exist.

public.name: getPixel32

parameters.name: x
parameters.help: The x coordinate of the pixel to be set. Must lay within the dimensions of this BitmapData.

parameters.name: y
parameters.help: The y coordinate of the pixel to be set. Must lay within the dimensions of this BitmapData.

returns.help: A native color value integer (format: 0xAARRGGBB)

public.help:
Get the color of a specific pixel including its alpha value.
If you have drawn anything to the BitmapData since it was created you must call BitmapData.update to refresh the array buffer,
otherwise this may return out of date color values, or worse - throw a run-time error as it tries to access an array element that doesn't exist.
Note that on little-endian systems the format is 0xAABBGGRR and on big-endian the format is 0xRRGGBBAA.

public.name: getPixelRGB

parameters.name: x
parameters.help: The x coordinate of the pixel to be set. Must lay within the dimensions of this BitmapData.

parameters.name: y
parameters.help: The y coordinate of the pixel to be set. Must lay within the dimensions of this BitmapData.

parameters.name: out
parameters.help: An object into which 3 properties will be created: r, g and b. If not provided a new object will be created.

parameters.name: hsl
parameters.help: Also convert the rgb values into hsl?

parameters.name: hsv
parameters.help: Also convert the rgb values into hsv?

returns.help: An object with the red, green and blue values set in the r, g and b properties.

public.help: Get the color of a specific pixel including its alpha value as a color object containing r,g,b,a and rgba properties.\nIf you have drawn anything to the BitmapData since it was created you must call BitmapData.update to refresh the array buffer,\notherwise this may return out of date color values, or worse - throw a run-time error as it tries to access an array element that doesn't exist.

public.name: load

parameters.name: source
parameters.help: The object that will be used to populate this BitmapData. If you give a string it will try and find the Image in the Game.Cache first.

returns.help: This BitmapData object for method chaining.

public.help:
Takes the given Game Object, resizes this BitmapData to match it and then draws it into this BitmapDatas canvas, ready for further processing.
The source game object is not modified by this operation.
If the source object uses a texture as part of a Texture Atlas or Sprite Sheet, only the current frame will be used for sizing.
If a string is given it will assume it's a cache key and look in Phaser.Cache for an image key matching the string.

public.name: processPixel

parameters.name: callback
parameters.help: The callback that will be sent each pixel color to be processed.

parameters.name: callbackContext
parameters.help: The context under which the callback will be called.

parameters.name: x
parameters.help: The x coordinate of the top-left of the region to process from.

parameters.name: y
parameters.help: The y coordinate of the top-left of the region to process from.

parameters.name: width
parameters.help: The width of the region to process.

parameters.name: height
parameters.help: The height of the region to process.

returns.help: This BitmapData object for method chaining.

public.help:
Scans through the area specified in this BitmapData and sends the color for every pixel to the given callback along with its x and y coordinates.
Whatever value the callback returns is set as the new color for that pixel, unless it returns the same color, in which case it's skipped.
Note that the format of the color received will be different depending on if the system is big or little endian.
It is expected that your callback will deal with endianess. If you'd rather Phaser did it then use processPixelRGB instead.
The callback will also be sent the pixels x and y coordinates respectively.

public.name: processPixelRGB

parameters.name: callback
parameters.help: The callback that will be sent each pixel color object to be processed.

parameters.name: callbackContext
parameters.help: The context under which the callback will be called.

parameters.name: x
parameters.help: The x coordinate of the top-left of the region to process from.

parameters.name: y
parameters.help: The y coordinate of the top-left of the region to process from.

parameters.name: width
parameters.help: The width of the region to process.

parameters.name: height
parameters.help: The height of the region to process.

returns.help: This BitmapData object for method chaining.

public.help:
Scans through the area specified in this BitmapData and sends a color object for every pixel to the given callback.
The callback will be sent a color object with 6 properties: `{ r: number, g: number, b: number, a: number, color: number, rgba: string }`.
Where r, g, b and a are integers between 0 and 255 representing the color component values for red, green, blue and alpha.
The `color` property is an Int32 of the full color. Note the endianess of this will change per system.
The `rgba` property is a CSS style rgba() string which can be used with context.fillStyle calls, among others.
The callback will also be sent the pixels x and y coordinates respectively.
The callback must return either `false`, in which case no change will be made to the pixel, or a new color object.
If a new color object is returned the pixel will be set to the r, g, b and a color values given within it.

public.help: Replaces all pixels matching one color with another. The color values are given as two sets of RGBA values.\nAn optional region parameter controls if the replacement happens in just a specific area of the BitmapData or the entire thing.

public.name: shadow

parameters.name: color
parameters.help: The color of the shadow, given in a CSS format, i.e. `#000000` or `rgba(0,0,0,1)`. If `null` or `undefined` the shadow will be reset.

parameters.name: blur
parameters.help: The amount the shadow will be blurred by. Low values = a crisp shadow, high values = a softer shadow.

public.help: Sets the shadow properties of this BitmapDatas context which will affect all draw operations made to it.\nYou can cancel an existing shadow by calling this method and passing no parameters.\nNote: At the time of writing (October 2014) Chrome still doesn't support shadowBlur used with drawImage.

parameters.help: The amount to shift the hue by.

parameters.name: s
parameters.help: The amount to shift the saturation by.

parameters.name: l
parameters.help: The amount to shift the lightness by.

parameters.name: region
parameters.help: The area to perform the operation on. If not given it will run over the whole BitmapData.

returns.help: This BitmapData object for method chaining.

public.help: Shifts any or all of the hue, saturation and lightness values on every pixel in the given region, or the whole BitmapData if no region was specified.\nShifting will add the given value onto the current h, s and l values, not replace them.\nThe hue is wrapped to keep it within the range 0 to 1. Saturation and lightness are clamped to not exceed 1.

class.help:
A Stage represents the root of the display tree. Everything connected to the stage is rendered

like: 0xFFFFFF for white

Creating a stage is a mandatory process when you use Pixi, which is as simple as this :
var stage = new PIXI.Stage(0xFFFFFF);
where the parameter given is the background colour of the stage, in hex
you will use this stage instance to add your sprites to it and therefore to the renderer
Here is how to add a sprite to the stage :
stage.addChild(sprite);

parameters.name: backgroundColor
parameters.help: the background color of the stage, you have to pass this in is in hex format

class.help:
The Keyboard class handles looking after keyboard input for your game.
It will recognise and respond to key presses and dispatch the required events.
Please be aware that lots of keyboards are unable to process certain combinations of keys due to hardware
limitations known as ghosting. Full details here: http://www.html5gamedevs.com/topic/4876-impossible-to-use-more-than-2-keyboard-input-buttons-at-the-same-time/

parameters.name: game
parameters.help: A reference to the currently running game.

public.help: Add callbacks to the Keyboard handler so that each time a key is pressed down or released the callbacks are activated.

public.help: If you need more fine-grained control over a Key you can create a new Phaser.Key object via this method.\nThe Key object can then be polled, have events attached to it, etc.

public.name: addKeyCapture

parameters.name: keycode
parameters.help: Either a single numeric keycode or an array/hash of keycodes: [65, 67, 68].

public.help:
By default when a key is pressed Phaser will not stop the event from propagating up to the browser.
There are some keys this can be annoying for, like the arrow keys or space bar, which make the browser window scroll.
You can use addKeyCapture to consume the keyboard event for specific keys so it doesn't bubble up to the the browser.
Pass in either a single keycode or an array/hash of keycodes.

If you need to control\nthat then see the addAt method.

Automatically creates multiple Phaser.Sprite objects and adds them to the top of this Group.
Useful if you need to quickly generate a pool of identical sprites, such as bullets. By default the sprites will be set to not exist

public.name: forEach

parameters.help: If set only children with exists=true will be passed to the callback, otherwise all children will be passed.

public.help:
Allows you to call your own function on each member of this Group. You must pass the callback and context in which it will run.
After the checkExists parameter you can add as many parameters as you like, which will all be passed to the callback along with the child.
For example: Group.forEach(awardBonusGold, this, true, 100, 500)
Note: Currently this will skip any children which are Groups themselves.

parameters.help: If child.key === this value it will be considered a match. Note that a strict comparison is used.

parameters.help: How to return the data from this method. Either Phaser.Group.RETURN_NONE, Phaser.Group.RETURN_TOTAL or Phaser.Group.RETURN_CHILD.

parameters.help: Optional function that will be called on each matching child. Each child of the Group will be passed to it as its first parameter.

public.help: Iterates over the children of the Group. When a child has a property matching key that equals the given value, it is considered as a match.\nMatched children can be sent to the optional callback, or simply returned or counted.\nYou can add as many callback parameters as you like, which will all be passed to the callback along with the child, after the callbackContext parameter.

public.name: set

parameters.name: child
parameters.help: The child to set the property on.

parameters.name: key
parameters.help: The property, as a string, to be set. For example: 'body.velocity.x'

parameters.name: value
parameters.help: The value that will be set.

parameters.name: checkAlive
parameters.help: If set then the child will only be updated if alive=true.

parameters.name: checkVisible
parameters.help: If set then the child will only be updated if visible=true.

parameters.name: operation
parameters.help: Controls how the value is assigned. A value of 0 replaces the value with the new one. A value of 1 adds it, 2 subtracts it, 3 multiplies it and 4 divides it.

parameters.name: force
parameters.help: If `force` is true then the property will be set on the child regardless if it already exists or not. If false and the property doesn't exist, nothing will be set.

returns.help: True if the property was set, false if not.

public.help: This function allows you to quickly set a property on a single child of this Group to a new value.\nThe operation parameter controls how the new value is assigned to the property, from simple replacement to addition and multiplication.

public.name: setAll

parameters.name: key
parameters.help: The property, as a string, to be set. For example: 'body.velocity.x'

parameters.name: value
parameters.help: The value that will be set.

parameters.name: checkAlive
parameters.help: If set then only children with alive=true will be updated. This includes any Groups that are children.

parameters.name: checkVisible
parameters.help: If set then only children with visible=true will be updated. This includes any Groups that are children.

parameters.name: operation
parameters.help: Controls how the value is assigned. A value of 0 replaces the value with the new one. A value of 1 adds it, 2 subtracts it, 3 multiplies it and 4 divides it.

parameters.name: force
parameters.help: If `force` is true then the property will be set on the child regardless if it already exists or not. If false and the property doesn't exist, nothing will be set.

public.help:
This function allows you to quickly set the same property across all children of this Group to a new value.
This call doesn't descend down children, so if you have a Group inside of this Group, the property will be set on the Group but not its children.
If you need that ability please see `Group.setAllChildren`.

The operation parameter controls how the new value is assigned to the property, from simple replacement to addition and multiplication.

public.name: setAllChildren

parameters.name: key
parameters.help: The property, as a string, to be set. For example: 'body.velocity.x'

parameters.name: value
parameters.help: The value that will be set.

parameters.name: checkAlive
parameters.help: If set then only children with alive=true will be updated. This includes any Groups that are children.

parameters.name: checkVisible
parameters.help: If set then only children with visible=true will be updated. This includes any Groups that are children.

parameters.name: operation
parameters.help: Controls how the value is assigned. A value of 0 replaces the value with the new one. A value of 1 adds it, 2 subtracts it, 3 multiplies it and 4 divides it.

parameters.name: force
parameters.help: If `force` is true then the property will be set on the child regardless if it already exists or not. If false and the property doesn't exist, nothing will be set.

public.help:
This function allows you to quickly set the same property across all children of this Group, and any child Groups, to a new value.

If this Group contains other Groups then the same property is set across their children as well, iterating down until it reaches the bottom.
Unlike with Group.setAll the property is NOT set on child Groups itself.

The operation parameter controls how the new value is assigned to the property, from simple replacement to addition and multiplication.

public.name: setChildIndex

parameters.name: child
parameters.help: The child DisplayObject instance for which you want to change the index number

parameters.name: index
parameters.help: The resulting index number for the child display object

public.help: Changes the position of an existing child in the display object container

public.name: setProperty

parameters.name: child
parameters.help: The child to set the property value on.

parameters.name: key
parameters.help: An array of strings that make up the property that will be set.

parameters.name: value
parameters.help: The value that will be set.

parameters.name: operation
parameters.help: Controls how the value is assigned. A value of 0 replaces the value with the new one. A value of 1 adds it, 2 subtracts it, 3 multiplies it and 4 divides it.

parameters.name: force
parameters.help: If `force` is true then the property will be set on the child regardless if it already exists or not. If false and the property doesn't exist, nothing will be set.

returns.help: True if the property was set, false if not.

public.help:
Sets a property to the given value on the child. The operation parameter controls how the value is set.
Operation 0 means set the existing value to the given value, or if force is `false` create a new property with the given value.
1 will add the given value to the value already present.
2 will subtract the given value from the value already present.
3 will multiply the value already present by the given value.
4 will divide the value already present by the given value.

class.help:
Allow to access a list of created fixture (coming from Body#addPhaserPolygon)
which itself parse the input from PhysicsEditor with the custom phaser exporter.
You can access fixtures of a Body by a group index or even by providing a fixture Key.

You can set the fixture key and also the group index for a fixture in PhysicsEditor.
This gives you the power to create a complex body built of many fixtures and modify them
during runtime (to remove parts, set masks, categories & sensor properties)

public.inlineHelp: This is called when the State is rendered during the preload phase.

public.inlineHelp: This is called when the State is updated during the preload phase.

public.name: onPauseUpdateCallback
public.inlineHelp: This is called every frame while the game is paused.

public.name: onPreRenderCallback
public.inlineHelp: This is called before the state is rendered and before the stage is cleared.

public.name: onRenderCallback
public.inlineHelp: This is called post-render. It doesn't happen during preload (see onLoadRenderCallback).

public.name: onResizeCallback
public.inlineHelp: This is called if ScaleManager.scalemode is RESIZE and a resize event occurs. It's passed the new width and height.

public.name: onResumedCallback
public.inlineHelp: This is called when the game is resumed from a paused state.

public.name: onShutDownCallback
public.inlineHelp: This is called when the state is shut down (i.e. swapped to another state).

public.name: onUpdateCallback
public.inlineHelp: This is called when the state is updated, every game loop. It doesn't happen during preload (@see onLoadUpdateCallback).

parameters.help: - The state you want to switch to.

parameters.name: autoStart
parameters.help: - If true the State will be started immediately after adding it.

public.help: Adds a new State into the StateManager. You must give each State a unique key by which you'll identify it.\nThe State can be either a Phaser.State object (or an object that extends it), a plain JavaScript object or a function.\nIf a function is given a new state object will be created by calling it.

public.name: checkState

parameters.name: key
parameters.help: The key of the state you want to check.

returns.help: true if the State has the required functions, otherwise false.

public.help: Checks if a given phaser state is valid. A State is considered valid if it has at least one of the core functions: preload, create, update or render.

public.name: clearCurrentState
public.help: This method clears the current State, calling its shutdown callback. The process also removes any active tweens,\nresets the camera, resets input, clears physics, removes timers and if set clears the world and cache too.

public.name: destroy
public.help: Removes all StateManager callback references to the State object, nulls the game reference and clears the States object.\nYou don't recover from this without rebuilding the Phaser instance again.

public.name: getCurrentState
public.help: Gets the current State.

public.name: preUpdate
public.help: preUpdate is called right at the start of the game loop. It is responsible for changing to a new state that was requested previously.

parameters.name: key
parameters.help: A unique key you use to reference this state, i.e. "MainMenu", "Level1".

public.help: Delete the given state.

parameters.name: clearCache
parameters.help: Clear the Game.Cache? This purges out all loaded assets. The default is false and you must have clearWorld=true if you want to clearCache as well.

parameters.name: parameter
parameters.help: Additional parameters that will be passed to the State.init function if it has one.

public.help: Restarts the current State. State.shutDown will be called (if it exists) before the State is restarted.

parameters.name: parameter

public.help: Start the given State. If a State is already running then State.shutDown will be called (if it exists) before switching to the new State.

public.name: alpha
public.help: The opacity of the object.

public.name: anchor
public.help:
The anchor sets the origin point of the texture.
The default is 0,0 this means the texture's origin is the top left
Setting than anchor to 0.5,0.5 means the textures origin is centered
Setting the anchor to 1,1 would mean the textures origin points will be the bottom right corner

public.help: The blend mode to be applied to the sprite

public.help: This is used to indicate if the displayObject should display a mouse hand cursor on rollover

public.name: cacheAsBitmap
public.help: Set if this display object is cached as a bitmap.\nThis basically takes a snap shot of the display object as it is at that moment. It can provide a performance benefit for complex static displayObjects.\nTo remove simply set this property to 'null'

public.name: children
public.help: [read-only] The array of children of this container.

public.name: defaultCursor
public.help: This is the cursor that will be used when the mouse is over this object. To enable this the element must have interaction = true and buttonMode = true\n

public.name: filterArea
public.help: The area the filter is applied to like the hitArea this is used as more of an optimisation\nrather than figuring out the dimensions of the displayObject each frame you can set this rectangle

public.name: filters
public.help: Sets the filters for the displayObject.\n* IMPORTANT: This is a webGL only feature and will be ignored by the canvas renderer.\nTo remove filters simply set this property to 'null'

public.name: height
public.help: The height of the TilingSprite, setting this will actually modify the scale to achieve the value set

public.name: hitArea
public.help: This is the defined area that will pick up mouse / touch events. It is null by default.\nSetting it is a neat way of optimising the hitTest function that the interactionManager will use (as it will not need to hit test all the children)

public.name: interactive
public.help: Indicates if the sprite will have touch and mouse interactivity. It is false by default

public.name: mask
public.help: Sets a mask for the displayObject. A mask is an object that limits the visibility of an object to the shape of the mask applied to it.\nIn PIXI a regular mask must be a PIXI.Graphics object. This allows for much faster masking in canvas as it utilises shape clipping.\nTo remove a mask, set this property to null.

public.help: Set to true to use pixel perfect hit detection when checking if the pointer is over this Sprite when it's clicked or touched.\nThe x/y coordinates of the pointer are tested against the image in combination with the InputHandler.pixelPerfectAlpha value.\nWarning: This is expensive so only enable if you really need it.

public.name: pixelPerfectOver
public.inlineHelp: Use a pixel perfect check when testing for pointer over.
public.help: Set to true to use pixel perfect hit detection when checking if the pointer is over this Sprite.\nThe x/y coordinates of the pointer are tested against the image in combination with the InputHandler.pixelPerfectAlpha value.\nWarning: This is expensive, especially on mobile (where it's not even needed!) so only enable if required. Also see the less-expensive InputHandler.pixelPerfectClick.

public.name: priorityID
public.help: The priorityID is used to determine which game objects should get priority when input events occur. For example if you have\nseveral Sprites that overlap, by default the one at the top of the display list is given priority for input events. You can\nstop this from happening by controlling the priorityID value. The higher the value, the more important they are considered to the Input events.

public.help: [read-only] The array of children of this container.

public.help: This is the cursor that will be used when the mouse is over this object. To enable this the element must have interaction = true and buttonMode = true\n

public.name: filterArea
public.help: The area the filter is applied to like the hitArea this is used as more of an optimisation\nrather than figuring out the dimensions of the displayObject each frame you can set this rectangle

public.name: hitArea
public.help: This is the defined area that will pick up mouse / touch events. It is null by default.\nSetting it is a neat way of optimising the hitTest function that the interactionManager will use (as it will not need to hit test all the children)

public.name: interactive
public.help: Indicates if the sprite will have touch and mouse interactivity. It is false by default

public.name: mask
public.help: Sets a mask for the displayObject. A mask is an object that limits the visibility of an object to the shape of the mask applied to it.\nIn PIXI a regular mask must be a PIXI.Graphics object. This allows for much faster masking in canvas as it utilises shape clipping.\nTo remove a mask, set this property to null.
